subject: Re: [junit] Re: Test Grouping/Partitioning
msgSnippet: Hi Cedric, ... 2+ years is in no time ? ;) Anyway, I ve once seen a build take well over 24 hours. It took them over 2 years to get there with several dozen
messageBody:
Hi Cedric,

On 7/18/07, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> On 7/17/07, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...> wrote:
> > Yep; that's a difference all right. I can't imagine having a test suite
> > that takes 10 hours to run.
>
> Just keep working on the same software for 2+ years, grow the size of
> the engineering team to 5-10 people, and you'll get there in no time.

2+ years is "in no time"? ;)

Anyway, I've once seen a build take well over 24 hours. It took them
over 2 years to get there with several dozen people and I'm still
amazed how is that possible. Since then, the build has been improved
slightly and is now somewhere in the vicinity of 2-3 hours, I believe,
including some linux server scratch installations.

Lasse

--
Lasse Koskela
* Author of "Test Driven" (Manning Publications, 2007) *
* Reaktor Innovations * http://www.ri.fi/en *
